channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Quiet strength? Regional friends pitch for issues-based coalitions
item.description: From the Quad to trilateral arrangements, purpose-driven partnerships are delivering where multilateral institutions struggle.

item.title: Great aspirations? Examining Russia’s role in Southeast Asia
item.description: A new book examines Russia's decade-long engagement with the region and finds more rhetoric than real influence.

item.title: Of hedgehogs and foxes: It’s time for a school of Australian statecraft
item.description: As a middle power, Australia needs both bold decision-makers and quick-witted rationalists. Those skills can be taught.

item.title: Zelensky Hears Out the U.S.-Russia Peace Proposal for Ukraine
item.description: A corruption scandal at home may force the Ukrainian president to reconsider Kyiv’s nonstarters.

item.title: Trump Turns His Eye to Sudan
item.description: The U.S. president said he’ll work with regional partners to help end Sudan’s civil war.

item.title: Nigeria Is Turning Into a U.S.-China Battleground
item.description: Trump’s threats leave Nigerians worried about superpower intentions.

item.title: China Is Worried About AI Job Losses
item.description: Beijing values domestic stability over global competition.

item.title: Transcript: An interview with Abbas Araghchi
item.description: The Economist speaks to Iran’s foreign minister

item.title: An interview with Iran’s foreign minister
item.description: Abbas Araghchi tells The Economist he wants a nuclear deal with America

item.title: Can AI Be Asia’s Next Growth Engine?
item.description: Asia’s growth model is under intense strain, and rapid population aging will only make matters worse. But, by fostering the skills people need to make use of AI and building institutions that enable them to apply those skills creatively, Asia's economies can unlock new sources of inclusive, durable growth.

item.title: The Dire Need for International Pressure to End the War in Sudan
item.description: The head of the Danish Refugee Council speaks about what she learned after meeting Sudanese refugees in Chad.

item.title: Electoral Roll Revision in India Sparks Widespread Social Anxieties
item.description: The Special Intensive Revision of the voters list across 12 Indian states could potentially lead to sharpening of the communal divide.

item.title: Is Russia’s Hybrid War on Europe Becoming Conventional?
item.description: From arson attacks on civilian targets to the recent bombing of a rail line between Warsaw and Ukraine, Russian provocations inside Poland are intensifying. By stoking anti-Ukrainian and anti-EU sentiment, the Kremlin hopes to empower the "useful idiots" of the Polish populist right.

item.title: India and the Blue Pacific: A partnership for climate security
item.description: Pacific Island countries demand respect for sovereignty and self-determination. Can India help build that vision?

item.title: South Africa Gets a Pass on Rampant Corruption
item.description: Why is a leading global watchdog turning a blind eye?

item.title: Academic Predators
item.description: The recently disclosed email exchanges between convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein and renowned economist Larry Summers illustrate a predatory dynamic in academia, in which professional support is implicitly traded for sex. A more equitable future requires an academic culture that repudiates the perverse norms of the old boys’ club.

item.title: Don’t Call It a Deal Just Yet: South Korea to Pursue Nuclear-powered Submarines
item.description: There’s a tremendous amount of uncertainty as to what was actually agreed to.

item.title: To glimpse Indonesia’s future, look to its president’s view of the past
item.description: Why Prabowo Subianto is rehabilitating the late Suharto

item.title: Where being antediluvian pays
item.description: Acting ahead of looming natural disasters can be a powerful tool

item.title: How will Japan’s defences evolve under its hawkish new leader?
item.description: Takaichi Sanae wants bigger budgets, better spooks and a stronger arms industry

item.title: The politicians protecting huge criminal networks
item.description: Investigations are growing, but change is unlikely

item.title: How Chinese underground banks became the world’s biggest money-launderers
item.description: They connect rich Chinese, drug cartels and North Korean hackers—without anyone meeting

item.title: AI is accelerating a tech backlash in American classrooms
item.description: Handwritten and oral exams are making a comeback

item.title: Release the Epstein files!
item.description: What Congress has actually voted to make public

item.description: It’s about more than denying inflation

item.description: In Ukraine, the wreckage is often gone before victims can recover their effects

item.description: Some shoes seem just too big to fill

item.title: Why Is Tajikistan Recalibrating Its Approach Toward the Taliban?
item.description: Tajikistan was a key external supporter of the Taliban’s opposition; its recent shift marks a departure from that role.

item.title: ‘Make Them Talk to Each Other’
item.description: Lessons in peacemaking from 21 days at Dayton.

item.title: Australia Revokes Visa of South African Neo-Nazi
item.description: At some point, liberal democracies have to draw a line about what they will and will not tolerate – and find ways to defend their open societies without destroying them in the process.

item.title: Europe Must Help Africa Break the Cycle of Debt
item.description: Unsustainable debt burdens, rising borrowing costs, and escalating climate shocks have left African economies with little fiscal space to invest in their future. Without a comprehensive reform of the global financial system, the continent’s development and Europe’s stability will face growing risks.

item.title: Africa’s other debt crisis
item.description: It is not just loans from China and Western financiers. Domestic borrowing is surging

item.title: A Self-Defeating Reversal on Ukraine
item.description: The Trump administration had actually begun to make progress. Now it’s all in doubt.

item.description: Many of the loans look harmless. But some are raising eyebrows

item.description: Many of the loans look harmless. But some are raising eyebrows

item.title: Mortgage lending in America is seizing up. How to revive it
item.description: Some rules introduced after the financial crisis have gone too far

item.title: Indians are getting more fashionable
item.description: Cheap data, cheaper clothes and improving logistics have made trends more accessible

item.title: Why governments should stop raising the minimum wage
item.description: After a decade of rises, there are now far better tools for fighting poverty

item.description: The returns to access in America are soaring

item.description: As Europeans debate who will fill the U.S. role on the world stage, an answer may already be apparent.

item.description: Recent curbs on computer chips and rare earths are feeding broader fears about deindustrialisation

item.description: If it does not, China and America will exploit the continent’s weaknesses

item.description: Where the loosening of rules and tolerance of corruption will lead

item.title: The Case for Taxing AI
item.description: If AI causes mass unemployment or severe fiscal shocks, elected officials and policymakers will need to act fast to limit the disruption. Fortunately, some of the most reliable and powerful options are also the most familiar.

item.title: Pakistan and the New World Order: Why an Old Mindset Cannot Survive a New Era
item.description: It could craft a new vision that honors the sovereignty of its neighbors and focuses on economic revival rather than regional conflict. Or hold onto outdated patterns of confrontation.

item.title: Why Have Baloch Separatists Not Weaponized Drones Yet?
item.description: Until they secure relevant technical capabilities to weaponize drones either by external knowledge transfer or internal learning, they may engage in strategic patience.

item.title: Climate change: Compromise and progress in the heart of the Amazon
item.description: Though outcomes might be less than hoped, important deals are being done at COP30.

item.title: What the World Missed in the Claudia Sheinbaum Groping Story
item.description: The president’s announcement of a crackdown on gender-based violence ignores its drivers.

item.title: The New Soft-Power Imbalance
item.description: China’s cautious response to America’s retreat.

item.title: How to Topple Maduro
item.description: And why regime change is the only way forward in Venezuela.

item.title: COP that: Australia trades hosting for climate talks presidency
item.description: Dreams of holding global climate negotiations in Adelaide may be dashed, but the compromise gives Pacific voices a lift.

item.title: What happens in Micronesia doesn’t stay in Micronesia
item.description: What dispersed basing reveals about US strategic priorities.

item.title: Myanmar Junta Announces Raids on Second Major Online Scamming Hub
item.description: The crackdown at Shwe Kokko marks an extension of the junta's anti-scam campaign, but there are reasons to be skeptical.

item.title: Is the GoTo-Grab Merger Finally Going to Happen?
item.description: The possible involvement of the Indonesian state investment fund Danantara could remove one of the primary roadblocks to a merger.

item.title: FIFA to Investigate Malaysian Football Body Over Document Forgery Scandal
item.description: The global sporting body alleges that seven foreign-born players used false documents to gain entry to the Malaysian national soccer team.
